You came to the wrong place.

The Honorable Elijah Muhammad teaches you, instead, to obey the law. To carry yourselves in a respectable way. And a proud Afro-American way. But at the same time...we teach you...that anyone who puts his hand on you? Do your BEST...to see he doesn't PUT HIS HAND on any...body...else...AGAIN.

I was born on a doorstep with a note 'cross my chest that read, "Do the best you can for him, world." I had to suck the first nipple come along. I didn't run away from home...I been runnin' to home.

dialogues.text: A door slams open. Cassius comes along the hallway, his entourage surrounding him. Three large middle-aged white officials accompany him, too. His face is set in stone. White towels are draped over his head onto his shoulders. Bundini chirps in his ear. Dundee, like a plumber, carryi the tools of his trade...a bucket, his swabs and Vaseline And they seem distant to Cassius. They reach the end of t corridor, and against the wall stand three or four older cigar guys. A curtain...the sounds from the arena drift into the hallway. Cassius is on his toes now, dancing, dancing. And as if being drawn by a force we can't see, h just goes...his entourage, as if holding on, carried alon by him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes into the hall...there are shouts, some scattered applause, some booing, growing; and the sound moves throu the arena...the sounds of expectations, ridicule, potenti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is struck by the brilliance. Illuminated, ready to go... dancing...warming up. Counter to an expectation of anxiet Cassius can't wait to get this on. Other sounds happen...irrelevant to him...and now the distant sound of Liston coming into the ring...his bulked-up presence, the roar he inspires, somewhere over there. And all of a sudd Cassius turns to face the angry man who wishes him death. Cassius rocks left and right, like a tough kid on a corne ready to rumble. The hysteria act is gone; so is the boasting. Instead, there is only Cassius' stare. The effect is enigmatic: what is going on here? A Referee, like a distant bird, says something we don't hear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: right away throws a left that misses and attacks Cassius, throwing seven more that Cassius with extreme, awkward caution evades.

dialogues.text: He is fearful of the monster whose punches he has yet to feel. Nevertheless, he does his job: measure Liston's range and speed. Then, a body shot catches him above the heart. Cassius feels the real power of Liston. It could stop your heart's beating. He survives. Then...

dialogues.text: throws his long left jab. It keeps Liston at a set distan He has Liston's range, now, and he dances away from Listo charges. Then, halfway through the round, Cassius' eyes have hunted out an opportunity, and he throws his first combination with a few hard shots that, to Liston's surpr rock Liston's head back. And, then, Cassius easily evades

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

And, now, infuriates Liston even more by merely walking away from Liston's big misses, provoking even wilder and more inaccurate Liston assaults. (We're aware that any Liston shot could knock out Cassius if it connected.) Then Cassi soaks up a couple of body shots, most flicks his jab, sli dances, clinches, circles away...UNTIL...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cassius, seizing opportunity, hits Liston with more combinations. If Cassius won Round One, probably but not certainly won Round Two, he now demonstrates he OWNS Roun Three. It's a symphony of classical Cassius Clay footwork flicked jabs that confuse, and, then, hard-hitting combinations that rock the presumably immovable Liston. N one told Sonny that Cassius could hit. And, at 210 pounds he hits HARD. Liston, angered, panicked, knows he's losin and goes after Cassius and misses wildly as the BELL ends Round Three...

dialogues.text: dominating. They clinch. They break. This time Cassius violently blinks his eyes! Something's wrong!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...my eyes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A knife-like pain. He can't see.     He's getting beaten He's in trouble. The BELL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) My eyes! I can't see...somethin' in my eyes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dundee feverishly washes water to get the irritant out of Cassius' eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A buzzer sounds, warning the bell's coming for Round Five Now Cassius stands, saying...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his gloves) Cut 'em off! Cut 'em!   I'm blind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BELL.    Dundee's still in the ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You quit, it's over! Get out there. Be a yardstick. This is the big one, daddy. Get out there and run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He literally pushes Cassius into the ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rushes Clay. He knows this is his chance. Cassius tries t tie Liston up by holding onto the back of his neck, but

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liston pounds left and right hooks. If anybody wondered i Clay could take punishment, this answers that. WHAM-WHAM- WHAM-WHAM-WHAM...five huge hooks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liston is desperate to end it while Cassius is in trouble Haymaker after haymaker; some connect, others are blocked but knock Clay sideways. Clay, still blind, keeps backing and dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a minute left, now, he sees better. Liston throws hi into a corner, still trying to put him away. But, he can' and Liston's energy seems to deflate once he knows that. The BELL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eyes are clear.   In 60 seconds he recovers his energy. ready. BELL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: can't wait to get out. He shuffles. He circles. He fires combinations. In the early rounds, provoked by Cassius, Liston's anger caused him to abandon his fight plan. Now, having been proven futile, Liston's confidence is gone. He's left with nothing. Psychologically and athletically, Liston is defeated. The BELL. Liston's eyes contemplate the inevitable: face nine more rounds of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: waits for the seventh-round bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doing color radio commentary with Les Kelter's blow-by-blow) ...Clay, a round ago, looked like he'd about had it, but in round six...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Cassius, knowing before anybody else, suddenly rises if on wings. Both arms are in the air...followed by a roa from the crowd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing, screaming) Sonny Liston is not coming out! Wait a minute! Wait a minute! Sonny Liston is not coming out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we can see Liston still sitting on his stool in his corner, spitting out his mouthpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The winner...and the new heavyweight champion of the world is Cassius Clay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassius jumps onto the ropes in the corner, rails the cro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I upset the world! I am the greatest! I am the greatest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All hell breaks loose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to press) Eat your words! Eat your words!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard Cosell, the first to climb into the ring, is on hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What made him so easy for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you. Didn't I tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bundini gives him a comb.   Cassius combing his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was there any single point you knew you had him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he sees Malcolm leaving his seat...they look at each other. Malcolm's huge smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had him in the first round. 'Cause I'm the greatest! (and seeing at ringside, calling him up) Sam... Hey, Sam! Let him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Sam Cooke climbs into the ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the greatest! And he the greatest rock 'n' roll singer. Sam Cooke! I want everybody to bear witness. (they embrace) I shook up the world! Don't have a mark on me! I was burning. I was blind. I'm the prettiest thing that ever lived. I shook up the world! I shook up the world!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sam Cooke embraces Cassius...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small older man with fine features, ELIJAH MUHAMMAD, TH MESSENGER, sits on plastic-covered furniture in his expensive living room. With him is an expressionless man who, literally, never smiles, in a tailored dark suit. He JOSEPH 13X. As Elijah Muhammad, the head of the Nation of Islam, contemplates Cassius' victory -- like everyone els in America, he's surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GORDON DAVIDSON is from the Louisville Sponsoring Group, standing in the chaos with another partner and Odessa and Cassius, Sr....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't care what should have been ordered! We need a victory party right now. (pause) I got national press, the family, the champ, all kinds of folks... (beat) 250 to 300. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: singing "Feel It." It's packed with elated people. Outsid celebrations spill out onto the streets...cars honking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: through the club, with lots of partygoers, picks up Chesterfields from the cigarette girl and goes out by poo around which we see women at tables in cocktail dresses a good-looking men. Most of the rooms' doors are wide open, couples drinking, celebrating...radios playing out into t Floridian night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and others of the Louisville Sponsoring Group in a crowd predominantly white people, drinking free drinks at the hastily arranged victory party, wait. Sportswriters...Jim Cannon, Red Smith. Cassius, Sr. is there. They all wait. No sign of Cassius. "Where's your boy?" A young New York Times sportswriter, ROBERT LIPSYTE, is there as well. He looks like he doesn't belong...his clothes are only perfunctorily conventional, and he's a generation younger

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: enters and closes the door and greets Malcolm X, in a whi shirt, no tie, and Cassius, eating ice cream in a pool of light from the TV. Malcolm's wife, Betty Shabazz, comes o of the kitchenette. A little girl runs from the bathroom back to Cassius. The girl plops into his lap with much familiarity, so we understand Cassius is family and has b for a while. He's not at the Fontainebleau or the Roney Plaza. It says Cassius' sense of himself is more about what's next than what he did tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's he so scared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, look at that guy run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassius feeds the girl some ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mummy! "I can't get away from the mummy!" Yeah, but that mummy too slow to catch anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!   The mummy always gets his man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he don't! (to kid) Now, don't believe that stuff on television...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter from the outside. Cassius looks. He's not drawn to all the partying. Malcolm takes a picture with his Contax. Through the door enters Jim Brown. Jim embraces Malcolm and Betty, Sam Cooke, and congratulates the new champ and helps himself to food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room's near dark. Soft sounds from outside. A laugh. A snatch of music. Malcolm's children are asleep on a cot And we see Cassius has fallen asleep on the sofa. A bedsheet is over him. Malcolm and Betty, sitting at the table in the kitchenette, quietly talking...an intimate laugh...partners. And as Cassius, the new heavyweight champion of the world, spends the first night of his reig asleep at "home" with this family...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly we're in Harlem. The streets are jammed. Making them crazy, causing a riot, coming down the sidewalk, looking like a rock-and-roll star in a black leather jack is CASSIUS CLAY and in an overcoat and hat, MALCOLM X. Th OWN this day on 125th Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: engulf them. People are their army. The sea of people press close to their heroes...reaching out to touch the champ, share a joke, laugh. A girl runs up to hug Cassius and runs off. We catch a glimpse on the periphery of Jose 13X. Seven or eight reporters, black and white, and still photographers and Bingham, half with Cassius, half photographer in privileged position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people look to you. Do you plan on being a people's champ, like Joe Louis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentative) Yeah. I going to be a people's champ... (beat) But not like Joe Louis, exactly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts) Mr. Clay...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cassius drops it on them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm not Clay. Clay's the name of the people who owned by ancestors. I don't want to be called after that slave name no more. So I'm "X." Cassius X. And I'm a member of the Nation of Islam. The Honorable Elijah Muhammad is my spiritual guide. Malcolm X is my mentor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is hard news!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all at once) You a card-carrying member?    Aren't Black Muslims a hate group?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (droll) "Card-carrying"...? Don't need no "card." You got a Christian card? 750 million people believe in Islam. I'm one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minister Malcolm...what about the reports of a split between you and Elijah Muhammad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEPH 13X:   we read his face listening to Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the champ's time. And I'm here as a friend to celebrate his victory. So I got nothing you want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to be a people's champion. But I don't have to be the way you want me to be. I'm gonna be what I want. And I'm free to think any way I want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, as he goes on, the crowd knows neither Cassius nor Malcolm will ever turn their backs on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: enters into the street with his Bodyguard and looks up to top-floor window in which he sees a light is still on at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: asleep with the television on. There's a knock on the doo Barely awake, he gets up to answer it. It's Malcolm. Stil in his familiar hat and overcoat. He hasn't slept...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was leaving, saw the light on...how come you're up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbles, half-asleep) ...watchin' a show on termites...they knockin' down this house, here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes back to lay on the bed. Malcolm looks out the window...the wet streets at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been invited to speak at Ibadan University in Nigeria. C'mon with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six million in your house and you don't know it. Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Africa.   You been there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Africa? No. Only Rome.      Yeah, man, let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nkrumah stayed with me when he was a student in New York, so we'll stop in Ghana...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm's distracted.   He fingers his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sees) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever been so angry...have you ever been so angry that you'd explode?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Tore out a picture of Emmett Till when I was little. Couldn't take my eyes to it...couldn't look at it. Barb-wire around his neck to a 75- pound cotton-gin fan. Took out his eye. The cruelty to it...I couldn't look at it...couldn't throw it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought, "What I do wrong to be so low that people could do that to people like me?" It made me feel ashamed. And that makes no sense. But that's what it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...when I heard about the four girls bombed in the 16th Street Church in Birmingham? (beat) The prohibitions of the Honorable Elijah Muhammad prevented me from speaking my voice in action. Because Birmingham was part of the civil rights movement, begging for a place at the white man's table... But dead children...are dead children. So the anger I felt, I had to contain. I locked that down! So tight my muscles seized. I lost control over the right side of my body. Leg didn't work...right arm didn't work. "I'm having a stroke," I thought. I had to hold it in 'cause I wanted, all I wanted was to BREAK SOMETHING! Break a part...any part of this system. Because you are so provoked as a human being. In your spirit. In your heart... At the death of children. But I COULD DO...nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassius is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting his glasses back on) Everyone knows... Now I'm advocating more direct political action involvement with the international struggle... So Elijah Muhammad has suspended me as a Minister in the Nation of Islam for 90 days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can fix that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I will try when we get back. Until then I will live each day as if I am already dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That statement surprises Cassius, but he says nothing. Malcolm X stands by the window and watches the day begin Harlem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: approaches Cassius in a suit and tie and beckons him into living room in which sits Elijah Muhammad on a plastic- covered white sofa. Cassius is at his most deferential, awed at being in this man's presence. Elijah's power is t inverse of his size. He's short and delicate-featured. He motions for Cassius to sit beside him. Joseph 13X sits across the room with two men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only after long service and high merit in the spiritual and physical rebirth of Afro-American people...is one granted an original name. But you are special. A world champion. So there is a gift I wish to give you. From this day forward you will be known as Muhammad Ali...which means "one worthy of praise," and Ali means "most high."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat, sounding it) Muhammad Ali. (humble) "Worthy of praise..." Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's genuinely moved. As Elijah Muhammad puts his sma hands in Muhammad Ali's hands...giving him his blessings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cautioning) Be very careful what you say...your words reflect on the nation of Islam, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Up until now, I have entrusted your spiritual development to Brother Malcolm. (beat) I do not feel this is a wise course anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extremely emotional about Malcolm, tears come to Elijah Muhammad's eyes. Joseph 13X observes in the background. Cassius is taken by surprise at "The Messenger"'s display

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm has gone off into the secular world and does not measure his words. I have decided to give you, as your guide, my very own son, Herbert Muhammad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he looks across the room...a roly-poly man wearing a tie...HERBERT MUHAMMAD. He has a habit of nervously straightening his shirt. A seemingly mild, pleasant man, is without self-definition. Below this avuncular surface, he defines himself by quietly desiring and acquiring what others'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herbert will supervise all of your spiritual and material needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not a thought) This is a great honor, Messenger...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elijah gives a subtle look and Herbert retreats to where came from, sitting back on the couch by Joseph 13X...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've entered mid-scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you want to change?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ali) Could we get a picture with you? (to Cassius, Sr.) You mind, Mr. Clay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A neighboring family coming to stand beside Ali.   Cassiu Sr. steps aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CASSIUS CLAY, SR., a sport, a flamboyant man, is impatien Inside, Odessa Clay and brother, Rudy, are talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with the lawyers and managers you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more. (click) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got...I got you the best white men I could find. Right here in L'ville...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the contract run out. I want black lawyers and managers. Chauncey Eskridge on North La Salle Street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) They saved you from the gangsters, from the jackals and the hyenas of boxing. Never cheated you. Protected you with a trust fund...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need no "protectin'" from myself. Why I need protecting from myself by them...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now I got to go tell them, "Piss off. Cassius don't want you around no more."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't one of their thoroughbreds! Or their charity things. "Let's do somethin' for that well-behaved colored boy, Cassius." I ain't well-behaved nothing! I am a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light starts to go...porch lights starting to come on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I am not Cassius. I changed my name. I am Muhammad Ali, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) What? What's wrong with...our name, my name...? We're...we made you. We...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one "made me"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No bow-tie-wearin', Arab-talkin' nigger gonna change that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anybody's son) I made me. (adamant) No one's in that ring but me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know who you are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who I'm not...I'm not drinkin'! Goin' back on my wife! I am not prayin' to no blue-eyed, blonde-haired Jesus. I ain't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paintin' blue-eyed, blonde-haired Jesuses and signs on cars is what put steak and vegetables in you, clothes on you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...dinner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we realize it has gotten too dark to see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold) Go ahead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitter silences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassius, Sr. walks off...his back arched too straight, trying to hold his pride together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't get it from me...your words, your sense of humor, what makes you angry, what makes you a fighter. You got that from your daddy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saying I'm just like him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saying, if he was your age today, he'd do the same as you. And he knows that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Odessa goes back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Malcolm at work at the kitchen table.      It's cl and small. The telephone rings...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy...    For you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm gets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother Malcolm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Joseph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Honorable Elijah Muhammad has given the Muslim name, Muhammad Ali, to Cassius X. Herbert Muhammad's been placed in charge of his training, instead of you. (and ultimately) Muhammad Ali will not be traveling with you to Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm's still.    He's been co-opted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Honorable Elijah Muhammad has asked me to inform you your suspension has been extended indefinitely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph 13X hangs up. Malcolm quietly closes the door. Malcolm dials a number. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty has come in.   They exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned for her husband) Malcolm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat, disconsolate) Cassius won't be coming to Africa...not with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her hand on Malcolm's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go anyway. Don't put it off.      It's not safe here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Mommy...the bath's ready...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in first class on a "Ghana Airlines" flight to Africa. Close by is Herbert Muhammad. Howard Bingham and Ali's brother, Rudy, are across the aisle from him, asleep... plane bumps in choppy air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muhammad, unable to sleep, a nervous flyer, gets up. He wanders up the aisle to the front of the plane. A Steward comes out of the cockpit. Muhammad slows, startled by the pilots. Both pilot and copilot are black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joking) Hey, man, where they put the real pilot? What you doin' up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not understanding; British accent) I am...the pilot. He's the copilot... (moves map case) Here, Mr. Clay, sit down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, man, I meant...in L'ville, when I growed up, they barely let black folks drive buses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali looks out the window...a new day downs over the land. Then Bingham shows up over Ali's shoulder. They all pose, facing the rear of the cockpit. Then, the Pilot points to the coast below them and the sunrise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we are. Cote d'Ivoire...Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: snakes out a building.   CAM FOLLOWS IT and we HEAR...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should think of a name, Malcolm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARLIN THOMAS -- paunchy, grey, late 40's -- walks up the stairs carrying take-out food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about Gamilah or Khalilah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: crosses to ANOTHER AMERICAN wearing headphones in the glassed-in balcony where the CABLE connects to a portable tape-recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eating) Anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...on the phone with his wife. She's having a hard time sleeping...baby's kicking a lot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motor Pool, here, have a Chevy parts catalogue...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the CIA monitors Malcolm X...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in a Mercedes convertible. It's a monumental expression o the force for the independence of black Africa. Accra is wonder to Ali. A Third World showplace, in 1964 Ghana is alive with the optimism of emerging Africa. Infrastructur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and real estate are well-managed. Under Nkrumah, the city is in a frenzy of building public housing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in the three-car caravan, passes the huge triumphal arch with its giant black star on the top. Thousands line the route to see the heavyweight champion and cheer him. For Ali it's another kind of parade...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're stockbrokers and street cleaners, salesmen and secretaries, hotel managers and military officers... All a contrast to the de facto apartheid of the middle Americ of Ali's experience. They all cheer his caravan as it pas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (GHANA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: arrives with Ali and entourage. It's a modern hotel. Meanwhile, a different group are about to depart in limos One among them, a tall Man in a dashiki and sunglasses an carrying a walking stick, separates. He sees Ali. So does the woman next to him. She is the poet Maya Angelou.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) Brother Muhammad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking off his shades, we realize it's Malcolm X. He wear a goatee, now. Ali turns, sees him. Total surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They embrace. Ali greets him like the old friend he is. Maya and the Chinese diplomat wait a few steps removed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doin'? What's up, brother? I knew you were here...didn't think you were still here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I heard you were coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just got here now... (words rush out) And, maaan, the brothers were flyin' a DC 8. Flippin' switches, navigatin', filing flight plans, talkin' French...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they remember how much they like each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When...uh, Liberia.   When you fighting Liston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: November.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Maya Angelou and Ambassador Huang Ha. Amando Gonzalez is from Cuba. Taher Kaid is the Ambassador from Algeria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali waves.   They keep their distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, where should I go?   We're planning on Egypt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Algeria. See Ben Bella... (beat) Go to Mecca, Medina. I just came back. Made my seven circuits around the Kaaba, prayed at sunrise... There were two million people...pilgrims from all over. Dressed all the same, high and low, the same. Blonde-haired, blue-eyed Muslims. Arabs. (off Ali's look of surprise) Blacks. Yeah. All of them, Muslims praying together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: who was surveilling Malcolm X in Cairo is here, too. Righ now he picks up the phone. REVEAL at the window an Africa Man and another American with binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...?

dialogues.text: She laughs and whispers something in Ali's ear, holding h hand where the others can't see it and slips her phone number to him. Meanwhile...a phone rings. Bundini answers while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: newspaper, to Ali) ...you gonna try for Germany?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna try to get stationed in Germany?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Champ.   It's Eskridge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Ali didn't know) They changed your classification. (turns page) It's in the paper...You're 1-A. You're gonna get drafted into the Army...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes phone) You know about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But I think the government's looking to negotiate a deal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hears on headset) Here we go...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wide World of Sports" is ON THE AIR.   We've entered mid broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I flunk their draft board test. Now, without testing if I am "wiser" or "worser," they decide I can go into the Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassius, it is my opinion you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cuts in) And I'm not Cassius Clay. That's a slave name. I'm a free man. I'm Muhammad Ali.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops, realizing) You know, I apologize to you. On the air. Your name is Muhammad Ali. You have the right to be called whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stays angry) You make a lot of mistakes for a so-called educated man. You really go to law school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Muhammad. And to think I gave up a lucrative practice for the likes of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the best thing that ever happened to you, Howard Cosell. Without me you be a tall white man with a microphone in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fast) And without me...you'd be a mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali lifts Howard's toupee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into camera) We'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali pours three spoons of sugar in his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Have a little coffee with your sugar...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep talking. You were saying something half-smart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want to make an example out of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? I'm no Stokely Carmichael, H. Rap Brown...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All they are is political. They tell people how they ought to be. But you are the HEAVYWEIGHT CHAMPION of the WORLD. You're important. And they don't like your militancy, your politics. So, they'll make an example out of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...of a good "Ne-gro," who do what he told?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Or, to demonstrate here is what happens to your ass if you don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's screwed either way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: waits at the curb as Ali and Herbert pull up and get out a car...move through the crowd...reporters shouting questions at him we don't hear, go up the steps, into the lobby, joining other recruits and M.P.'s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) You do six weeks basic...you go into the Reserves...you don't go to Vietnam...you get to box...you even get to keep the money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives Ali a piece of paper signed by the Justice Department, confirming the deal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lets him know) The Messenger would not object if you joined under these terms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stay out of jail and I get to fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) All you have to do is accept the induction. And life goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They call your name. You say yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not sure what Ali will do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lined up with the twenty-five other inductees...being addressed by an Induction Officer, Naval LT. JEROME CLARI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and you will take one step forward as your name and service are called, and such a step will constitute your induction into the Armed Force indicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Claridge begins to read the names, and services...the young Men dutifully stepping forward. Ali expects his nam to be called. Instead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassius Marcellus Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quiet. Dead quiet. Ali's lips move. NO sound comes out. We anticipate him stepping forward...he doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Clay, I am required to inform you that refusal to accept a lawful induction order constitutes a felony under the Universal Military Training and Service Act, punishable by up to five years' imprisonment and a five-thousand-dollar fine. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO FBI AGENTS in suits have appeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeats) Cassius Marcellus Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a third time) Cassius Marcellus Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herbert's dying.    Ali "stands his ground..." and the di been cast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (presenting badge) Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Clay, you're under arrest for refusing induction...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they turn around and handcuff him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: approach from two vehicles. Rudy and SIX LARGE MUSLIMS escort Ali through the crowd of media trucks, reporters a conspicuous unmarked police cars and neighborhood people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: waves in Robert Lipsyte, the New York Times sportswriter his late 20's we've seen before. He and Howard Bingham, waiting inside, know each other. They enter. The phone's already RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on the phone, on a long extension, joined by Lipsyte and Howard Bingham, while Bundini keeps at bay reporters at t front door. It all feels like a rock group in town for a concert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (listens; to cam.) Ask Chauncey Eskridge in Chicago. He's my lawyer. No. I'm out on bail. (goes onto balcony [rear shot]) Yeah, I fight. I fight clean. I'm an athlete. Army's there to kill, kill, kill. My religion forbids that. No. I never shot anything in my life. (turns) Do I know where Vietnam is? (wry; playing to Bingham) Yeah. It's on TV... (beat) In southeast Asia? It there, too? (beat) That's a joke, man...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali hangs up.   The phone rings again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated) What do I think about who?      Vietcong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next is something Ali has not deduced. Ali perceives it intuitively and reflexively. As with other of his decisio once made, he doesn't hesitate to speak them. And he won' waver. He says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I ain't got no quarrel with them Vietcong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes dead silent.   Ali listens.   Lipsyte is stunned. So's Howard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Vietcong ever called me nigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what you j-j-just said...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Europe to China...every home in America...the world's gonna know what the heavyweight champion of the world said about the U.S. war...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what? (beat) I ain't gonna be what anybody else want me to be. I'm not afraid to be what I want. And think how I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's the real Ali, right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: laying on the sofa. Dundee, Pacheco and Rudy have joined. There's the feeling the house is a bunker. Phones ring. Television is on. LIPSYTE, taking notes, watching Walter Cronkite on TV. He crosses to Ali. Dundee's on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Nixon, the Republicans, Boxing Commission in New York, Cleveland and L.A. (a foregone conclusion) But you're also getting attacked as unpatriotic by the NAACP, Roy Wilkins, Jackie Robinson, the New York Times and Joe Louis...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The expression on Ali's face is blank, as if he's accepti a pounding: he knows what it is; it's not a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very low ceiling; we're in a green-lit cavern with a lo ceiling. Chauncey Eskridge and Ali wait. Ali's in the backseat of a 1961 Lincoln. Two FOI guards stationed at t distant ramps allow a Black Oldsmobile to pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a New York lawyer and promoter arrives and climbs out of Oldsmobile. Ali opens the door...but doesn't get out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Arum) People are following me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got almost nowhere I can promote a fight for you. Plus, I think they're going to vacate you from the crown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   If you're convicted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gonna take away what no fighter in the world can?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And New York may revoke your boxing license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you want to do all this? (politics) Your next three to four years are every heavyweight's prime. And there are few of those years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What 'bout Terrell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll know if we can fight Terrell in Illinois this afternoon. Terrell's running his mouth. He said if you're called, you should serve...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Motherfucker. He got a deferment for bein' too tall, or havin' flat feet. Why don't he serve for me? Tellin' me what I should do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ali + Eskridge) I got to get you some fights.    Fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali's quiet, not really listening anymore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wearing a suit and a narrow tie at a table in front of Da machine apparatchiks. A bald man, angrily:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand we could take away your license to fight Terrell in Illinois?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you prepared to apologize? About your unpatriotic remarks that you made?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apologize? No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said that you were the people's champion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you're acting like the people's champion...?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I am not going to apologize to you. This isn't a courtroom. And I don't have to sit here and answer your questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali gets up and walks out on them.   Eskridge and NOI men black suits follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: march through the lobby. Ali gives a walking interview. He's angry. He won't slow down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't draft dodgin'! I ain't goin' to Canada. I ain't burnin' my draft card. I ain't burnin' the flag. I'm stayin' right here. And you want to throw me in jail? Go ahead. I'll do my time. I been in jail four hundred years. I'll be in jail four, five more. But I ain't goin' ten thousand miles to help murder and kill poor people for you. 'Cause if I'm gonna die, I'll die now, right here, fighting you. If I wanna die. You my enemy, not Vietcong or Chinese or Japanese. You my opposer when I want freedom. You my opposer when I want justice. You my opposer when I want equality. You want me to go somewhere for you, but you won't even stand up for me in America, for my rights and beliefs, you won't even stand up for me here at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ERNIE TERRELL is taller than Ali. The empty stadium has a scale and press at one end. Girls in cowboy hats and lone stars say we're in Texas. Ali is distracted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting on scale) Tell Clay he can get on after me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get on the scale after...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cuts in) What you call me...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrell wrongly thinks there's psychological value in provoking Ali.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only thing I knows you as:   Cassius Clay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (infuriated) Announce it right here or from flat on your back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali throws a punch that doesn't land because he's separat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's my name?!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: something else in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hit FOUR TIMES by Ali:   WHAM, WHAM, WHAM, WHAM!   In the glaring lights...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's my name, motherfucker?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Ali flicks out punches...disorienting Terrell.   The

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAM! WHAM! WHAM! Ali hits him five times...Terrell ties him up. Ali throws him off, slips two jabs and snaps his left into Terrell's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali, at the apex of his athletic skills, fires six- or eight-punch combinations and then changes direction. Ali shoots jabs and hooks going backwards; every move and set combinations is a dance. Ali's never been as light on his feet, as fast, as complex as in this fight. Like any mome of greatness, we want it to last forever... Then, Ali throws a 17-punch combination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT'S MY NAME?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that burns down Terrell. Terrell starts to fall. Ali moves away. He doesn't want it to end. Sportswriters don' like it. Half the fans don't like it. Ali defies both their sensibilities and their politics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: face is battered.    Ali SLAMS in SHOTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouted) My name?! WHAT'S MY NAME?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BELL ends the savage pounding. Ali in the middle of t ring, glorying in opposition and triumph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with Eskridge and his other attorneys. The courtroom's packed. In the back we spot Joe Smiley, anonymous in the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Judge) If the court would give me my sentence right now instead of waiting and stalling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obliges) My pleasure. The jury has found you guilty of refusing induction into the United States armed forces. I sentence you to the maximum sentence allowable...five years' imprisonment and a fine of ten thousand dollars. (pause) Fast enough? Your attorney will lodge an appeal. While you're out on bond, I order your passport surrendered. I'll not have you benefitting yourself by fighting abroad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on his way out of the building.    Media is held at the o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looks dazed, not sure how to act on the way out of court. Oddly, he shakes hands with each of a half a dozen white Houston Bailiffs. It's as if, benumbed by the verdict, he seeks human contact. The only contact available, ironical is with the officers of the court that just convicted him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time has passed. It's winter. Snow's on the ground. He's in a car coat and a hat with a hooded sweatshirt undernea Street lights are on. Traffic's slight. He walks through the whiteness as new snow falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: under the hat brim, his gaze is internal, as it was in th opening in Miami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with icicles from Fire Dept. water. His work boots stop deep in the new falling snow...vanishing in the WHITEOUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in Ali's hands. He leans across a white showcase of baker goods. It's cold outside; warm inside. It smells of bread and coffee. BELINDA BOYD reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes a fist, balls the scarf up, and puts it in the hollow of his fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offering) Blow on it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She blows on it. She's not quite eighteen, six feet tall; there's a supremely confident expressiveness about her. H gestures are large. He opens his hand. The scarf is gone. She instinctively looks over at his other hand. Nothing's there. His eyes go wide in mock fright at the mysterious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This spooky! Don't get scared...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs. How'd he do it? He makes a fist again, puts his thumb in the hollow. And slowly pulls the scarf out..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) See, you don't need to fight no more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives it to Belinda. She ties it around her neck. Ali looks at her. On a cold and dark afternoon, the windows a steamed and the bakery seems a fine refuge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's fresh, girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Everything fresh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) What's the freshest of the freshest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Doughnuts just came out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds up the doughnut) Feed me those things, I gotta come back as a wrassler. (a ring announcer) 645 pounds. I'd still be pretty...but I be fat pretty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't remember when you met me once before...long ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joking) I remember something...   Wha's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slaps his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know my name! You came to my school, right before you win the title. Interviewed you for the school paper. I was eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had a long braid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! You called me little Indian girl, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved you then, like all those kids. I never stopped. I still do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finishes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The African-American Albert Speer-regimented seating brea up. Ali's wearing a black suit, a white suit and white ti As he drifts through the crowd, approaching him is Belind in a white caftan and a white satin turban with gold earrings. It feels like they are an official couple, eugenically chosen mates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: join.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: touch. She turns and leans back slightly against him... Their thighs touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We walk past the bakery. It's closed.     Ali crosses the guttered street and exits into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: enters. CTA bus passes. Eskridge is there, waiting for hi Ali takes a coffee in a paper cup and grabs a Danish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see the Ellis-Quarry fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... We'll be in front of the U.S. Court of Appeals next month. We'll lose. Then we appeal to the Supreme Court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellis the champ? Man. I beatin' on him since we was sixteen. They give Ellis to Joe Frazier? Frazier'll kill him. Then they out of juice. Where's the gate? So they gotta let me fight. I fight Ellis in a phone booth...middle of Times Square...you think that draw a crowd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draw a crowd or not draw a crowd, Muhammad, is NOT going to make a difference with your boxing licenses. They don't want you to fight. (so much for speculation) ACLU's handling your case against the New York Boxing Commission. They discovered New York's got actual ex-murderers and ex-rapists currently licensed to fight. But revoked yours...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tijuana?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. State Department refused permission for the one-hour visa. No fight in Tijuana. Look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't fight here. Can't fight outside the country...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know people in the restaurant business...want to start up a chain. Muhammad Ali's "Champ Burger"..."Muhammad Malts," "Fist Full of Fries"...all of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start out towards the gas pumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why I want to be in the restaurant business?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause you need the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much all this gonna cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too much.    They do that to you, too, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They seek to destroy every facet of Ali's life. Ali knows that. As they pass the pumps. Some customers recognize hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to customers) Look out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, champ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Ali pretends to start sparring. The working men laugh One is brave enough to raise his hands, too. Ali smiles a trades a couple of phantom slaps. It breaks off. He made their day. He shakes each of their hands. His spirit's raised, he walks off. Chauncey watches this ritual...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hands and skin and faces against white in bed.   So close are intimately inside the moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First time? 1961...Sister Khalilah introduced you at assembly. You said you would be heavyweight champion of the world by the time you were twenty-one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always tell the truth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was eleven. I interviewed you for the student paper. You called me "little Indian girl," 'cause I wore my hair real long, in a braid...I told you..."Man, you scribble! You can't even write! You ought to go back to school until you do it better..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughing, he starts poking her in the ribs, and she turns onto him. She's six feet tall, he's six-three. He grabs her wrist. She wrestles him down on the large bed until there's a NOISE, and Belinda separates from Ali and approaches a smaller bedroom to replace the bottle their daughter, MARYUM, threw out of her crib. As she exits, MO IN on the crib in streetlight and we HEAR Jimi Hendrix's bottleneck instrumental part of "All Along the Watchtower It makes us feel the child in the crib is threatened, and that takes us INTO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in a black leather jacket with a white shirt and skinny t speaking to an audience of college students, white and bl some Asian and Latino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from "All Along the Watchtower") "There must be some kind of way outta here, said the joker to the thief..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingham waits in the wings. Applause. Ali joins Howard an a small group watching a portable TV...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: occurring on Chicago's North Clark Street. Off-screen we HEAR police sirens. On TV, Weathermen attack lines of Chicago police! The cops fall back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "There's too much confusion, I can't get no relief. Business men, they drink my wine, plowmen dig my earth, None of them along the line, know what any of it is worth."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: trains in grey sweats to Hendrix. He flashes 60 sit-ups hanging off a table. He sweats profusely. He has no trainers. Bingham holds his legs. Ali seems heavier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gym is grimy, filled with other boxers, a forest of heavy bags. Ali's one among other guys working out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: grimacing through another set, trying to stay in shape, trying to retain skills going dormant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "No reason to get excited, the thief, he kindly spoke. There are many here among us, who feel that life is but a joke."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, he's slow on the heavy bag.   Sparring alone in the ring... Everyone ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEAL Ali + Bingham watching the 1968 Olympics. NOW, Tom Smith and John Carlos bow their heads and raise fists in black power defiance, instead of acknowledging the nation anthem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "But you and I, we've been through that, and this is not our fate. So let us not talk falsely now, the hour it's getting late..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the coverage cuts to George Foreman with a small American flag in his hand. Then, it flashes back to Ali i the ring with Sonny Liston at his feet. And Ali coming ou of the Illinois Boxing Commission, angry. Dead Black Panthers, Fred Hampton and Matt Clark murdered by police Chicago. And Malcolm X and Ali together. The meaning of i is clear: MUHAMMAD ALI IS THE WARRIOR SAINT IN THE REVOLT OF THE BLACK ATHLETE IN AMERICA. On Ali watching, as a phone rings...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "All along the watchtower, princes kept the view, while all the women came and went, barefoot servants, too."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: speaks to Ali on a pay phone on ground level.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...struck out at the appellate level in New Orleans. So we're heading back to the Supreme Court...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought we already got turned down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm petitioning on a conscientious objection basis. Religious belief. We'll petition that your sincere religious belief prohibits you from shooting people. I believe they'll hear that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fast car drives by, distracting Ali momentarily.   Then Ali focuses 100% on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the money come from, Chauncey? Herbert tell me I'm runnin' on empty. Put aside "how do that happen"? Licenses all revoked. No passport. I can't fight here. Can't fight abroad. (beat) And what happen if I lose the Supreme Court?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all over. You go to jail for five years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no response from Ali.   Ali hangs up, looks the o way, lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hangs up the phone. Looks up. Starts to dial another number. A sound CRACKS OPEN THE NIGHT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauncey runs up the stairs to the second-floor balcony t join...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cradling Martin Luther King, Jr. in his arms. People SCRE King involuntarily spasms. Under King, dark blood pools like crude oil. Eskridge, ANDREW YOUNG and JULIAN BOND point into the Memphis afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as if they were pointing at a burning fire, sirens, blue police flashers, an isolated gunshot. And REVEAL Ali on a rooftop, in sweatpants, sweatshirt, SHADOWBOXING while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Outside in the cold distance, a wild cat did growl, two riders were approaching, and the wind began to HOWL!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves off to look into the distance. The agility, wha he was with Terrell, isn't there. He exhales in time with punches HUH, HUH, HUH...Ali's struggling to hold onto diminishing sharpness. Police lights. Looting? He contemplates the fabric of the city ripping itself apart while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on ABC. REVEAL Ali with Maryum in his arms watches the fight...an activity from which Ali, the resident genius o the planet, is excluded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellis doesn't belong in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curt) Man give him a shot, he took a shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw Bundini in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...bad shape. You better get your belt b-b-back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belinda brings coffee to Bingham...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got to be done with that bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call your parents, Ali?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he didn't. I told them about the one on the way...myself. (moves to the kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You p-p-p-promised you'd call them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call 'em, I'll call 'em... (re: the baby) May-may! It go in one end and come out the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna try changing her, for the experience?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You so much better at it, mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belinda takes Maryum. FRAZIER holds his arms up in victor a formality of applause from the half-empty Garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Maryum) Maaan...Joe Frazier can't talk, can't up the gate, can't fill the arena. They gotta let me fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That happen, you promise me you put some new people around you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali crosses to kitchen phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need Angelo, Rudy, Ferdie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali, she's talkin' about "Brother" Herbert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali stops. Between him and Belinda, this is important: solidarity is with her husband, not with the NOI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they when we need them? You got Gene Kilroy droppin' off groceries like charity. Borrowin' money from my folks. So...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ali contemplates what she's said, we HEAR...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are your feelings about up- and-coming Ken Norton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still sweating) Norton's big and strong, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's talking into Howard's period headset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Hold on one second...we have a caller. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Cosell? This Muhammad Ali.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A still photo of Ali in an iris appears superimposed on monitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to Georgia or Alabama or Sweden. Everybody know I'm the champ. The crown is a lie. I know it's a lie. Joe Frazier know it's a lie. It time for everybody to stop lying and tell the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's tell it like it is. With your court and boxing problems, Muhammad, can you get a fight promoted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't interested in the paycheck, I'd fight Joe Frazier for free in a phone booth in Times Square, if I wasn't broke. I still will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you say you were broke?   How can you be broke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elijah Muhammad reacts to the interview on television. There's a formality to Elijah Muhammad, even at his kitch table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've made more money than all previous heavyweight champions combined. What about your management? Surely they have provided for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saying it's time for everybody to quit lying! Muhammad Ali is the champ! I have to, I'll get the fight on myself. (beat) And if they offer me money, I ain't gonna turn it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CROSSCUT:    Elijah turns to an aide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me my son, Herbert, on the telephone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: training. There is NO entourage with him. Ali hits the heavy bag. He doubles up the left jab on the taped-togeth heavy bag. Sweat stains his sweats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: runs through tall reeds in the abandoned industrial landscape, ending at the lakefront and the cold, open sky and water. He's breathing hard, struggling against time t hold onto shape and prowess. He seems vulnerable against the open sky and water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elijah Muhammad is at the lectern ringed by Fruit of Isla Guards. HERBERT is behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Muhammad Ali desires to do that which the Holy Qur'an teaches him against. I am, therefore, suspending Mr. Ali from the practice of Islam. He may no longer appear in temple, pray or teach, or have any conversation with any Muslim whatsoever. Furthermore...he may no longer use the name of Muhammad Ali. Henceforward, he will revert to his old slave name, Cassius Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sits at the table. A deep vacancy is beginning to be ther we've never seen before. May-may makes a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muhammad...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't call me that no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I can't. I'm defying them by talking to you. And being with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVE CLOSER and CLOSER into Ali's eyes. He's oblivious. Belinda's pregnant again. She says something to him. Ali can't hear. She says it again, louder. Ali doesn't look a her. OVER ALI onto the Formica table with Log Cabin syrup and powdered sugar and ceramic salt and pepper shakers SE in his ECU, disconnected, depressed, withdrawn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: entering, concerned and urgent...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whyn't you call an ambulance or a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following behind) Wouldn't let me. Said he knew you...and to call you, Mr. Ali... He's not been out for three days...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali's up the stairs, down the corridor and takes the key from the lady and opens the door. It's a dump. Rotting food, something burned on the stove. On the floor, wrappe in a threadbare bedspread, half in and out of the bathroo which is foul, is Bundini, sleeping off a drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bundini!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opens his eyes; half sits) Watchu' doin' here? Gimme that short dog!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali -- his concern crashes. He detests the type Bundini resembles. He throws a half-empty half-pint of Old Taylor against the wall. It splatters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you, man?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin' wrong with me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali goes to the curtains and pulls them back.    Bundini, blinded...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What that?!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mystery...d-d-d-daylight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shielding his eyes) Leave me alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I leave you alone.   You called me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That were a week ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali grabs Bundini's arm and twists it and pushes his slee up. Bundini tries to pull his arm away. Ali is way stronger. Track marks up and down Bundini's arm. Ali slap Bundini on the side of the head. SMACK! He slaps him agai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you shame yourself like this for, maaan...?! Why you shame yourself?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bundini flails back with his arms.    Ali leans in and SM him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme alone! (shouts) I'm flyin'! The Sky Chief talk through me. I know the word!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know "low." You so low, the curb look like up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (demonstrates) Yeah? The king gotta go home to his throne! From the root to the fruit...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those rhymes is old.    Forget 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (demonstrates more) God don't care about you! Don't care about me! In all of everything, we mean nothin'. He don't know us. We be. And that's the onliest thing he did. And that's good 'cause that's why we free. But free ain't easy. Free is real. And realness is a motherfucker... (low; almost spooky) It eats raw meat. (beat) It walk in its own shoes. (beat) It does not waver... (pause) Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a pause in the room.    Bundini crashes.    He st crying, unabashedly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sold your belt for five hundred dollars to a barber on Lenox Avenue. That's how low I did you. I'm filled with weakness and got a crazy mind. That belt say you the Heavyweight Champion of the World. Five hundred dollars and I put it into my arm. That's what I called to tell you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali leans back against the wall...the last vestige, gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...heard 'bout the Nation, all that court stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (absent) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Muhammad.    Take me back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. There's no "back" to take you to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali gets up -- Bundini has been taken from him, too -- an leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and beyond the side of Ali's face, elevated through the slums and decrepit tenements of the south side of Chicago...the mean alleys and decaying back porches. Men gathered around 50-gallon steel drums, burning wood for warmth. Everything is corrupted or has left him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: staring into nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: The city recedes. Vectors, in perspective, carry structur buildings away. The sky is grey, going to blue. The city flees and SUDDENLY disappears as we race into the dark tunnel of subway. Ali's lost in the depths of attempting calculation. He can't do that for which he has a genius beyond other men...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) ...you can't do what you do best in the world. And how you feed your family? From prison? Who take care of your kids? And is Allah, is God with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's been exiled from the belief system that explaine the universe to him. SUDDENLY LIGHTS slash across his fac in the white-tile North Avenue station. BEYOND, ghostlike working men and two heavyset women enter. Ali turns aside to prevent being recognized. It's the first time he's eve avoided the public. The train lurches forward...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: screams away from us. Red reflects off the rails past Ali face as we descend deeper into the tunnels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: steps out of the truck. There is a small crowd of people who turn as ALI pulls up in a convertible. He's solemn fo a moment. Then he's out of the car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand dollars to the man who brings me Howard Cosell's toupee! Dead or alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reveal Ali next to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud) Don't bother me. I'm a world- famous broadcaster and you're an ex-champion with diminished skills. I can't be seen you, it would be calamitous to my reputation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: alone in the convertible parked in a distant corner of th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put me on, Howard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muhammad, I'd do anything for you. But I got bosses who only give a damn about Nielsen ratings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guarantee...it will be a historical and momentous night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali being interviewed by Howard Cosell in the "Wide World Sports" set. We've entered mid-scene...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...what Heavyweight Champion of the World? I'm not the champ. I am retired, finished, out of the game. And I ain't gonna let myself grieve and suffer none. But I know I will not fight again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were resolute in your resolve to regain your crown...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If tomorrow they say: "We want you to fight Joe Frazier. Madison Square Garden. Millions and millionses of dollars. Here's your license back." I will tell them: "I am sorry, but I am done."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Frazier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to wonder...what me and Smokin' Joe would have looked like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You surprise me, Muhammad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard, you losing your hearing along with your hair? Don't put questions to it! (beat) I am through fighting. 'Cause I got a bigger and more important match comin' up. The U.S. government. A heavier contender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you're going to jail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but it's going to be a shocking and terrible fight. In fact, they might wish they let me stay in boxing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Frazier told me on this show he would knock you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you go, agitatin'. (beat) You ask Smokin' Joe what he been smokin'?! Joe Frazier even dream he can whup me? He better wake up and apologize... (pause) But, if I WAS to jump in the ring with Joe, here's what you might see... (recites) Ali comes out to meet Frazier, but Frazier starts to retreat; If Frazier goes back an inch farther, he'll wind up in a ringside seat; Ali swings with a left, Ali swings with a right. Frazier keeps backin', but there's not enough room. It a matter of time before Ali lowers the boom; Now Ali lands with a right, what

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a beautiful swing, But the punch lifts Frazier clean out of the ring. Frazier's still risin', but the referee wears a frown, 'Cause he can't start countin' 'til Frazier come down. And Frazier's disappeared from view. And the crowd is getting frantic. Then our radar stations pick him up. He's somewhere over the Atlantic. Who would have thought when they came to this fight, That they would witness the launching of a black satellite?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's laughter off-camera in the studio and a wry smile Cosell's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't wait for they fight. 'Cause it ain't never gonna happen. You only can wonder and imagine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phones in the master control booth and ringing off th hook...the public's reaction to Ali's Bre'r Rabbit routin Ali used his ability to command presence in media to prom the only fight the public wants to see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to buy you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali's dad sits on a crate, painting the door of a deliver truck. He looks up...Ali is there. Emotion wells up in both men. The younger "rebelistic" son, seeing his father who is so like him. The older hep-cat who got cheated by life of his potential and promise. In this case, his boy, his boy's name, pride and reflected glory...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't drink no more. (squints at him) You wanna fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna fight no more.   Not with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they embrace, Odessa comes out, watches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali stands on the street corner, shades, incognito. A gol Cadillac pulls up: JOE FRAZIER. He is wearing a lemon yellow cowboy outfit, Stetson hat, striped pants. Ali loo at him in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who dress you, Joe?   You look like Dale Evans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.    Get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali gets in, Frazier takes off. He sits sideways on the seat, steers with one finger, flicks on the radio: Isaac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell you in Philly for? Philly my town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be closer to you, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There be two undefeated heavyweight champions! And they ain't fighting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna fight you! Said it a hundred times. The Man won't let you fight no more. What you complainin' to me for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause you gotta get behind this and we gotta do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
